TPAREA Ref: RBK.05.76T.1Address: Kingdom Hall 29A Alexandra Road Kingston Upon Thames KT2 6SDTree category:  Details:

AIRCZ Type:: Heathrow Planning Consultation Zone: All buildings, structures, erections and works exceeding 90 metres in height (295.3 feet)Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Heathrow Airport Limited, c/o Planning Services, First Point, Buckingham Gate, Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH6 0NT

description: Demolition of an existing  single storey building and erection of a two storey building to accommodate 4 x apartments and 4x outdoor parking spaces.
decision_conditions: Any rainwater goods used in the development to which this permission relates shall be cast iron or aluminium cast iron effect.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Unless expressly shown otherwise on the approved plans, the flat roof area(s) of the development to which this permission relates shall not be used as a roof garden, balcony, seating area or other similar amenity area, and shall not be accessed except for the purpose of maintenance or in the case of emergency.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, any windows or rooflights at second floor level or above in the eastern, northern or western elevations shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with and permanently retained in obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable, tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, privacy screening, 1.7m in height as measured from the floor level adjacent to the screen, shall be erected along the northern, eastern and western sides of the roof terraces. Aside from essential fixings, the screen(s) shall be constructed entirely of obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable, tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Any external lighting installed at the site shall be angled so as to prevent any spillage or glare beyond the site's boundaries.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of the means of enclosure to be erected both within the site and along its boundaries shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The approved means of enclosure shall be implemented in full prior to beneficial occupation of the development and shall be permanently retained as such thereafter.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, the drainage system as shown in Drainage Strategy ref:191212/DS/MK/RS/01 and dated February 2020 shall be implemented in full and permanently maintained thereafter.Reason: To prevent the development from increasing the risk of flooding to the site itself or elsewhere, in accordance with policy 5.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, evidence showing that the development has achieved at least a 19% improvement in CO2 emissions versus Part L of the Building Regulations and internal water usage rates of no greater than 105L per person per day have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy 5.2 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with the following documents:Arboricultural Method Statement dated 31 October 2019Arbtech AIA 01 dated Feb 2020Arbtech TPP 01 dated Feb 2020The approved measures shall be implemented prior to commencement of any work on site and maintained to the reasonable satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority until the completion of the development.Reason: To safeguard trees worthy of retention and in the interests of the character and appearance of the area, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, a detailed scheme for all hard and soft landscaping, including replacement of all felled trees on a two-for-one basis, shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following substantial completion of the development. The tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority.Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced during the following planting season, and the areas shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of waste and recycling facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The refuse and recycling facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development and shall be permanently retained thereafter. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development are either stored within these facilities or internally within the building(s) on the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material is stored or placed for collection on the public highway except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure proper waste management in the interests of the character and appearance of the area and the living conditions of neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policies 5.17 and 7.4 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of secure cycle parking facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.The cycle parking facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained for that purpose and kept free from obstruction thereafter.Reason: To ensure that appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport are taken up, in accordance with policy 6.9 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The garaging or car parking shown on the approved plans shall be provided with a hard-bound, adequately-drained, dust-free surface prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained and kept free from obstruction thereafter. It shall not be used for any purposes other than the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of and visitors to the development.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, a car parking management plan (detailing how electric vehicle charging points will be provided and how the car parking spaces will be allocated) shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The development shall then be carried out in strict accordance with the approved plan.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

No development shall take place (including any works of demolition) until a construction management plan or construction method statement has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:i) How the proposed development will be built;i) Hours of working (which shall be limited to 08.00 to 18.00 Mondays to Fridays and between 08.00 to 13.00 on Saturdays and not at all on Bank Holidays and Sundays);iii) The procedure for loading/unloading materials;iv) The route to and away from site for muck away and vehicles with materials;v) The protocol for managing deliveries to one vehicle at a time on sites with restricted access or space;vi) The protocol for managing vehicles that need to wait for access to the site;vii) Whether any reversing manoeuvres are required onto or off the public highway into the site and whether a banksman will be provided;viii) Temporary site access;ix) Signing system for works traffic;x) Whether site access warning signs will be required in adjacent roads;xi) Whether it is anticipated that statutory undertaker connections will be required into the site;xii) The storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles;xiii) The potential for impacts from dust and emissions during the demolition and/or construction phase upon local air quality and surrounding residents;xiv) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works;xv) The location of all ancillary site buildings;xvi) The means of enclosure of the site, its erection and maintenance;xvii) Wheel washing equipment;xviii) The parking of vehicles of site operatives and visitors;xix) Meeting the requirements of the Low Emission Zone for Non-Road Mobile Machinery (where relevant plant or vehicles are being used); andxx) The method of recycling and disposing of waste resulting from the demolition and/or construction phasesDeliveries/collections to and from the site shall use a route that is agreed with the highway authority and the agreed route shall be signed accordingly.Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase.

In the event that contamination is found (at any time) that was not previously identified, development shall cease and the contamination reported in writing to the local planning authority as soon as is reasonably practicable. An assessment, remediation scheme and verification report shall then be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority before development resumes.Reason: To ensure that risks from land contamination are minimised, in accordance with policy 5.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended).

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, samples of the facing materials to be utilised in the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The development shall then be carried out in strict accordance with the approved samples.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, detailed drawings at a scale of 1:20 of the following features shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority:(i) windows, including depths of reveals, any aprons, sills, mouldings, heads, jambs, transoms, mullions, lintels or revealsThe development shall then be carried out in strict accordance with the approved drawings.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The rooflights in the development to which this permission relates shall be of a conservation style, constructed in timber and set flush with the plane of the roof in which they are inserted. The rooflights shall be permanently retained in this style. Reason: To prevent harm to the significance of designated heritage assets, in accordance with policy 7.8 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM12 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The site comprises a dental practice, located within Kingston Vale Conservation Area and the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill, Strategic Area of Special Character.Consultation- 11 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.- Malden And Coombe CAAC - No response- Building Control - Comment receievdThe key areas of assessment are:- The impact of the proposal on the character and appearance of the area; - The impact of the proposal on heritage assets;- The impact of the proposal on neighbouring residential amenity; and- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. Heritage AssetsParagraphs 193 to 202 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.Officer Comment:  As noted above the proposal would generally be in keeping with the Residential Design SPD and would not detract from the character and appearance of the surrounding area, as such officers conclude that the proposed development would not result in any harm to the Kingston Vale Conservation Area or the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Officers have assessed the impact on daylighting and sunlighting of the proposed extension, using the BRE, 45 Degree Rule and the Residential Design SPD, to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities.Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties and neighbouring extensions, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.A fire safety strategy has been submitted and the following comments have been provided by the Building Control team: - The maximum travel distance for means of escape in a single direction is typically 18m and where escape is possible in two directions, this can be extended up to 45m. - The proposed extension would result in the single direction of travel exceeding the allowable 18m and as such, a secondary 'means of escape' would be required - which has provisionally been provided, however it is unclear where this exit leads to and how it will be managed.- BC is unable to allow for how the building and its escape routes are managed following completion of the building work - this would be down to the building's management plan.- If the proposals are unable to provide a satisfactory secondary means of escape, they may need to adopt a different approach involving a fire engineered design or change the proposals.As it stands, officers conclude that the proposal would not comply Policy D12(A) of the London Plan. In conclusion, the proposed development would not be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).
Condition 17 (Public Art) - RBK Arts and Culture Officer has reviewed the information submitted and is satisfied this can now be approved.

17. A public art and way-finding strategy should be submitted to the local planning authority for approval prior to commencement of above ground works. The public art and wayfinding strategy shall identify proposed public art and way-finding works to be installed as part of the detailed landscaping strategy. The Strategy shall detail the mechanism for selecting the public art and way-finding works and the maintenance and management of the art works. The works of art shall be installed prior to the beneficial use of the car park or in accordance with the timeframe set out in the public art and wayfinding strategy and thereafter retained in accordance with the agreed maintenance and management plan.Reason: To provide public art that will enhance the public realm in accordance with Policy D8 of the London Plan.The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above, are agreed and that the proposed strategy proposed pursuant to Condition 17 (Public Art) of Planning Permission 22/02905/FUL shall be carried out in accordance with the strategy hereby approved.

In accordance with the lawful development certificate 21/03734/CPU, the applicant is reminded that the use of the outbuildings shall only be incidental to the general enjoyment of the dwelling house, that is to say they should not be used as a separate self-contained residential dwelling / planning unit. Should it be determined that the use of the outbuildings extend beyond an incidental use, based on fact and degree and on the particular merits of the case, the applicant is advised that this would constitute a material change of use and would require planning permission

You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Councils Environmental Health Department.

The development hereby approved may include the carrying out of work on the public highway. You are advised that before undertaking the work on the highway you must enter into a highway agreement under s171, s184 or s278 of the Highways Act 1980 with the Council. You will be required to pay fees to cover the Council's costs in undertaking the approval and inspection of the works.

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.ProposalConsultation2 Neighbouring properties have been notified and following amended plans being submitted on 03.01.2023 a further 14 day consultation letter was sent. Overall, 6 objections from 2 different addresses have been received stating;- Effects on trees- Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Inappropriate design/layout- Loss of light/Sunlight- PrivacyIt is noted that that application form states there will be no loss of trees, however, it is noted that the tree root protection area of nearby trees would possibly be affected from the proposed development. The site and adjoining sites, are not covered by a Tree Protection Order (TPO).  AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire SafetyDesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment:The application proposes the construction of a single storey extension to the rear of the dwellinghouse. Policy Guidance 33 (Single Storey Rear Extensions) of the Residential Design SPD 2013 states that single storey rear extensions should bedesigned so that they appear proportionate and subordinate to the host building. In all cases, the following guidance applies: If the neighbouring property has a different rear building line, then the depth of the extension could be increased. In all cases, at least 50% of the rear garden should remain. Extensions should generally not exceed 3m to 3.5m in depth. Extensions with a flat roof should not exceed 3m in height. Extensions with a parapet roof should not exceed 3.3m in height. Extensions with a pitched roof should not exceed 4m in height.The proposed extension would measure 5.3 metres in depth, and would have a flat roof measuring approximately 3.4 metres in height. The excessive depth and height of the proposed extension, hard up to the boundary with No. 57 Cambridge Gardens would ensure that the development would not appear proportionate and subordinate to the original dwellinghouse. The proposed development is therefore considered to not be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be an adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: The principal properties to consider in relation to amenity are No. 57 and No. 61 Cambridge Avenue. The proposed development would be situated to the rear of the existing dwellinghouse. With specific regards to No. 57 Cambridge Avenue, due to the excessive depth, officers anticipate that the proposed development would have an unacceptable impact on the light and outlook of neighbouring habitable room windows, resulting in an undue sense of enclosure. It has not been demonstrated that the proposed development would be compliant with BRE guidance in relation to daylight/sunlight. It is therefore considered that the proposed development would adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyPart A of Policy D12 (Fire Safety) of the London Plan (2021) sets out that "In the interests of fire safety and to ensure the safety of all building users, all development proposals must achieve the highest standards of fire safety and ensure that they: 1) identify suitably positioned unobstructed outside space:   a) for fire appliances to be positioned on   b) appropriate for use as an evacuation assembly point2) are designed to incorporate appropriate features which reduce the risk to life and the risk of serious injury in the event of a fire; including appropriate fire alarm systems and passive and active fire safety measures 3) are constructed in an appropriate way to minimise the risk of fire spread4) provide suitable and convenient means of escape, and associated evacuation strategy for all building users 5) develop a robust strategy for evacuation which can be periodically updated and published, and which all building users can have confidence in6) provide suitable access and equipment for firefighting which is appropriate for the size and use of the development.Officers Comments: No Fire Statement has been submitted to demonstrate how the proposed development addresses the requirements of Part A of Policy D12 of the London Plan (2021). Therefore, it has not been demonstrated that the proposals would achieve the highest standards of fire safety.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling, located in the Grove Crescent Conservation Area of which The special architectural and historic interest of this area can be summarised as: A planned mid-Victorian estate of houses of various sizes and styles, the core of which forms the Spring Grove Estate, including St John's Church, a school, and local shops.Officers note that this application follows a recently refused application 22/03229/HOU dated 07/12/2022. The reason for refusal was as follows;1) The proposed development would be incongruous and jarring when viewed within the street scene and would not respect the character of the existing dwelling or the wider area. The proposed development would cause less than substantial harm to the Grove Crescent Conservation Area which would not be outweighed by any public benefit. The proposed development is therefore contrary to Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012), the Residential Design SPD (2013), Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) and the NPPF (2021).This application would need to address this reason for refusal.21 neighbouring properties have been notified and 1 representations has been received in support of the application.Kingston Town Neighbourhood Conservation Areas Advisory Committee - No comments have been provided for this application but it is noted that they raised an objection to the previous application stating; 'The proposed rear dormer is large (almost full width of roof) & would be clearly visible from the public highway (Denmark Road). Furthermore, it would be out of character with the neighbouring properties, none of which have rear dormers. This would cause harm to the character and appearance of the CA.'RBK Tree and Landscape Officer - No objection as would not cause harm to trees in Conservation areaThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development and the impact on the Grove Crescent Conservation Area- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of and  buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.Policy DM12 is clear that the Council will: 'ensure that development proposals affecting historic assets will use high quality materials and design features which incorporate or compliment those of the host building or the immediate area' and preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design.Officer Comment:  Officers acknowledge that the proposed dormer has been reduced in size. However, the use of zinc cladding still remains and would still be considered to be inappropriate within the Conservation Area. The rear dormer would be highly visible from Denmark Road to the rear and would not complement the character of the original dwelling. The proposed materials would not complement the existing roof tiles. It would appear incongruous and jarring in appearance from the street and to the original property by way of its overall design.  It is considered, on balance, that there would be an unacceptable adverse impact on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposals.Officers consider that the dormer addition would amount to less than substantial harm to the conservation area and it is therefore necessary to weigh this against any public benefits of the proposal. The applicant has not advanced any arguments as to the public benefits of the proposal, nor is it apparent to Officers that there would be any. The proposed development would fail to preserve the character and appearance of the conservation area and there would be no public benefits to outweigh the identified harm, thereby conflicting with Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) and Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Core Strategy 2012.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in conflict with Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended), Policies CS8, DM12 and DM10 of the Core Strategy (2012), the Residential Design SPD (2013) and the NPPF (2021).

The assessment has been based on the original layout of the house which shows a small outrigger to the rear. The proposed extension would therefore extend beyond the side elevation of the original footprint and would have a width greater than half the width of the original dwellinghouse, in conflict with Paragraph A.1 (j) (iii) of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended).

Condition 103 (Highway Works)- Officers have reviewed the information submitted and are satisfied that evidence has been provided showing both TFL and RBK Highway Engineers have approved the highway works through a Section 278 agreement.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above, are agreed and that Condition 103 (Highway Works) of Planning Permission Ref. 16/10482/FUL is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above, are agreed and that  Condition 24 (Construction Logistic Plan) and Condition 26 (Construction Environmental Management Plan (CEMP)) of Planning Permission 17/10342/FUL are hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling located on the Clevedon Road. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints. Proposal Erection of single storey rear extension (following demolition of existing conservatory)Consultations6 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed single storey rear extension would replace the existing conservatory, it would be of similar depth of approximately 3.1m, the proposed eaves height would be approximately 2.5m and the total height of approximately 3.8m, following Policy Guidance 33 of the Council's Residential Design SPD.The proposal would not be visible within the street view therefore there would be no impact on the existing street scene as a result of the proposal.Given the above, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development due to its siting and modest scale would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. The proposal would pass the 45 degree rule in relation to the both adjoining properties. The proposed high level window to the west side elevation is considered to be acceptable in this case, as the existing rear extension at the adjoining property has no openings to the side. Therefore there would be no loss of privacy or undue overlooking in relation to No 8 Clevedon Road as a result of the proposal. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a semi detached 3 storey townhouse located within the Woodside Road/Eastbury Road Local Area of Special Character and Flood Zone 2. Proposal Demolition of existing porch and entrance and erection of single-storey side extension, conversion of existing garage to habitable space and associated changes to fenestration.Relevant Planning History 22/01188/HOU -  Demolition of existing porch and entrance and erection of single-storey side extension, conversion of existing garage to habitable space. Replacement of existing timber balustrade with 1100mm increased height metal balustrade. Installation of 1no rooflight and associated changes to fenestration -  Refused on 21.06.2022Consultations4 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- The impact of the development on the Local Area of Special Character and,- The impact of the development on the existing car parking facilities;and,- Fire Safety; and,- Flood RiskCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The current scheme is a revised proposal of the previous planning application 22/01188/HOU refused due to the following reason (in relation to character and appearance):1. The proposed single storey side extension by reason of its siting, size and design (not being set back from the front elevation) and type and colour of the proposed materials would create an incongruous addition to the host property that would be visually intrusive and detract from the character and appearance of the host property and the immediate surrounding area. This would have an unacceptable impact on the character and appearance of the immediate surrounding area and would result in harm to the significance of the Woodside Road/Eastbury Road Local Area of Special Character. The proposed development would therefore conflict with Paragraph 203 of the NPPF, 2021, Policy Paragraph HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 It is noted that the proposed side extension would be set back from the front elevation by 500mm and its width would not exceed 50% of the original house, in accordance with Policy Guidance 35 of the Council's Residential Design SPD. The proposed, modest height of the parapet roof would be approximately 3.2m. The proposed flat roof form is acceptable in this case as similar developments are present within Watermans Close, for example the existing side extension at the adjoining property. The proposed replacement of all the openings to be similar in appearance to the existing ones and installation of a rooflight is considered acceptable. As the proposed conversion of garage into habitable space with associated alterations is a common feature on Watermans Close, it is considered that it would not have significant impact on the host dwelling and the surrounding area. It is noted that the balcony balustrade at the first floor would be refurbished, matching the existing materials and design. The proposed materials would be similar in appearance to the existing ones and  therefore are considered to be in keeping with the host dwelling, other properties within Watermans Close and the immediate surrounding area. Given the above, it is considered that the applicant has overcome the previous reason of refusal, and due to the siting, design and proposed materials of the side extension, the proposed development is considered acceptable  It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: It is considered that the proposed development due to its siting, design (no new openings are being proposed to the side elevation) and modest height would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Non-Designated Heritage AssetsParagraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF 2021 set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.Paragraph 203 states that the effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining any application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement is required, having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.The application property falls within the Woodside Road/Eastbury Road Local Area of Special Character which is a non-designated heritage asset. As stated above Officers consider that the proposed development would not result in an adverse impact to the host property or the character and appearance of the local area of special character. It follows that Officers consider that the proposed development would  not result in harm to the significance of the Woodside Road/Eastbury Road Local Area of Special Character.Car ParkingDespite the loss of the existing garage, it is considered that the hardstanding to the front of the dwelling, as demonstrated on the proposed plans, remains of an adequate size to accommodate one off street car parking space, therefore the proposal would not result in an unacceptable impact on the local highway network.It is noted that conversion of the garages and parking in front/at the back of the properties is a common feature at Watermans Close. Notwithstanding the submitted plans indicating location of  the proposed cycle parking to compensate for the loss of the garage, further details to demonstrate secure cycle parking and the proposed materials and design for the cycle (and bin) storage would be secured via condition. The existing on-site car parking space is shown to be retained.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.Flood RiskThe application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2. Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. The submitted plans show that the proposal would be set no lower than the main dwelling, however a flood risk assessment form that includes appropriate mitigation measures to be implemented as part of the proposed development should be submitted in order to comply with Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling. The site is located within the Old Malden, Area of Archaeological Significance.Consultations7 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 2 objections have been received, relating to:-Excessive height of bulk of buildings- Inappropriate design/layout- Loss of light/sunlight- Privacy The concerns raised will be taken into consideration during the assessment of the application and detailed below.The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. - The impact of the development on highways and transportation matters.- The impact of the development and non-designated heritage assets; and, - Fire SafetyDesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Officers note that the ground floor rear extension would not respect the residential design SPD in regards to the flat roof design, however, it would follow the height guidance of 3m for proposed flat roofs. It is also acknowledged that the proposal would sit at a greater depth than 4.9m when considering previous rear extension(s), this would fall outside the guidelines of the Residential Design SPD, Policy Guidance 33. Nevertheless, the proposal would sit at the same depth as adjoined semi-detached No. 10 Church Road. On balance, officers consider the proposed rear extension to be acceptable in regard to character and appearance.The proposed two-storey side/rear extension would have a flat roof which would not fall in line with the Residential Design SPD, as the host dwelling has a pitched roof design. The proposal would also not be set in from the boundary by 1m, however, officers would not consider this a detrimental issue, as the gap between the two dwellings has already been significantly eroded. Additionally, the proposal would only be slightly visible from the streetscene and the applicant proposes matching material and similar fenestration use and there already exists some flat roof at first floor level. Overall, on balance, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Officers have assessed the impact on daylighting and sunlighting of the proposed rear extension and the two storey side extension, using the BRE, 45 Degree Rules and the Residential Design SPD to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities. Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. TransportationPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: The dimensions of the proposed garage would not safely accommodate on-site car parking, as such, would not comply with the space parameters required by the Sustainable Transport SPD, 2013. However, it is noted that the hardstanding to the front of the property would provide 2 adequate car parking spaces, which would be acceptable levels of on-site car parking. HeritageParagraph 203 of the NPPF 2021 states that the effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining any application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement is required, having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Core Strategy 2012 sets out the Council's commitment to preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design and a focus on heritage-led regeneration. The Council will allow alterations which preserve or enhance the established character and architectural interest of a heritage asset, its fabric or its setting, and will ensure that development proposals affecting historic assets will use high quality materials and design features which incorporate or compliment those of the host building or the immediate area. Features of local importance and special interest will be respected through the consideration of form, scale, layout and detailed designs of a site, area or streetscape.Officer Comment: As noted above the proposal would reasonably adhere to the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD and would not be visible from the streetscene. Therefore, the proposal would not detract from the character and appearance of the surrounding area, as such officers conclude that the proposed development would not result in any harm to the Old Malden, Area of Archaeological Significance.Historic England (Archaeology) was not consulted on this proposal as the proposal would not fall within the following catergories:- Major planning applications over 0.5 hectares whether in an APA or not- Environmental Impact Assessment Scoping requests and Environmental Statements- Applications supported by an archaeological desk-based assessment- Minor planning applications in any APA (tiers 1 to 3)- Domestic basement applications in APA tiers 1 and 2 only. Note: For boroughs as yet without APA tiers consult GLAAS on any domestic basement in an APA.- Householder and equivalent-scale very minor applications in APA tier 1 only. Note: For boroughs as yet without APA tiers do not consult GLAAS on householder or equivalent applications unless within 50m of a scheduled monument.- Proposed substantial demolition or major alterations to historic buildings- Submission of details in relation to archaeological conditions- Appeals on applications for which an archaeological issue has previously been identifiedAs such, no comment would be required from Historic England (Archaeology).Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why the development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a detached dwelling. The site is located within the Groves Conservation Area.8x neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 1x representation has been received, highlighting the following concerns:-- Effects on trees- Loss of light/Sunlight- a neighbouring property would be deprived of a lot of light. - The loss would result in the angle of side light "significantly below 45 degrees" from the side. - The "current boundary of the existing garage is already at the 45 degree side light limit".- The drawings of the proposed extension, "do not show how this window is affected adversely by the reduced angle of light from the side".- A request from a neighbour that "the new proposed building is limited to the existing boundary of the garage."- A neighbouring study/playroom window would also "have its light blocked" by the proposed extension.- A neighbour has noted a "significant loss of light was the grounds that the previous planning proposal was rejected."- "Increasing the wall higher than the existing garage wall", would block light to windows to a neighbouring property.= The proposed drawings show a red line indicating a 45 degree angle of light to neighbouring windows from "above the new wall".  However, in "accordance with guidelines on the Council website", the measurement should be a 25 degree angle from our windows, in the horizontal plane, to the top of the proposed new wall. Therefore the neighbour believes "the new wall should not be so high."- The Host Property has an existing a double story extension at the back of the house. - "The boundary of the original house ended at the garage. So this proposed extension of the garage would be an extension on top of an existing extension."- The proposed extension is in a conversation area adversely affecting flora & fauna.- Addition of 3 velux windows to the roof of this new building, would cause privacy issues.Case Officer comment:- The RBK Tree Officer In comments made for the previous identical scheme (22/03155/HOU}, had no objections to the proposals. There will be a slight loss of natural light to the neighbouring property at no.96 and the applicant for the current application has incorrectly indicated a 45 degree daylight line instead of a 25 degree daylight line. However, the side windows at no.96, facing the host property are set away from the proposed development, there is an existing garage to the side of the host property and the windows to a study/playroom are not classed as those to a habitable room under Building Regulations. The proposed single storey side extension would therefore not have a significant impact on no. 96 Chestnut Grove in terms of daylight/sunlight, or overbearing appearance. The addition of 3 rooflight windows to the roof of the proposal would not cause significant privacy issues, as a result of these being at a high level and not directly facing neighbouring side facing windows. The remainder of the concerns highlighted in this representation are addressed later in this report.RBK Tree Officer (In comments made for an identical scheme 22/03155/HOU}:- I have no objections to the proposals The trees to be removed as part of the proposal are more shrubs and lapsed hedging and they are not contributing to public amenity.Maldens & Coombe Neighbourhood Conservation Areas Advisory Committee- No ObjectionRelevant Planning History00/04315/FUL- Erection of a two-storey rear extension- GRANTED 27.02.200122/03155/HOU- Erection of single storey side extension (following demolition of existing garage)- REFUSED 30.11.2022 for the following reason:-The applicant has failed to demonstrate through the submission of cogent information that the proposed single storey side extension would not have an unacceptable adverse impact on no. 96 Chestnut Grove in terms of daylight/sunlight and overbearing appearance. Given the scale of the extension and the proximity of neighbouring widows it is considered that there is a likelihood that the development would breach the BRE guidelines and reduce light entering into the neighbouring windows, which in turn would harm the residential amenities of the occupant(s) of the neighbouring property. As such, the proposal is therefore contrary to policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings;- The impact of the development on designated heritage assets;- Transportation; and,- Fire Safety.	DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed single storey rear and side extension is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, or loss of light As such, the proposal is therefore in accordance with policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.Officers consider that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of loss of privacy.  HeritageSection 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.Paragraphs 194 to 203 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC 1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Core Strategy 2012 sets out the Council's commitment to preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design and a focus on heritage-led regeneration. The Council will allow alterations which preserve or enhance the established character and architectural interest of a heritage asset, its fabric or its setting, and will ensure that development proposals affecting historic assets will use high quality materials and design features which incorporate or compliment those of the host building or the immediate area. Features of local importance and special interest will be respected through the consideration of form, scale, layout and detailed designs of a site, area or streetscape.Officer Comment: The special architectural and historic interest of this area can be summarised as a planned estate of roads laid out in the 1850s by the National Freehold Land Society, an early building society dedicated to voting reform, with plots developed in an individual and piecemeal fashion throughout the 19th & 20th centuries.As noted above, officers conclude that the proposed development would not result in any harm to the significance of The Groves Conservation Area, but rather preserve it. As previously mentioned, the proposed development would be in keeping with host property and as such would maintain the character of the immediate surrounding area. Given no harm to heritage assets has been identified in this case, it is not necessary to weigh up the proposals against any public benefits.TransportationPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: The proposal would involve the replacement of an attached garage to the side of the property, with a ground floor side extension. However, the existing hardstanding to the front of the dwelling would be sufficient to accommodate one spaces for on-site parking. The PTAL for this part of Chestnut Grove is 2. Taking into account the maximum car parking standards set out in the London Plan, which are up to 1 space per dwelling, for an Outer London PTAL 2 - 3, 3+ bedroom dwelling, it is considered that this issue would not warrant grounds for refusal, given that it is reflective of the existing situation.Fire Safety AssessmentLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which can be secured through condition.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.7 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations has been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings;- Fire Safety Assessment.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment:  Officers note that the proposal would have a large footprint, however it would have a modest height, maintains 500mm front the neighbouring boundaries and given that it would be situated in a fairly substantial rear amenity area, officers consider that it would appear a subordinate addition to the host property, and would not detract from the character and appearance of the surrounding area.While officers note that the proposal would have many characteristics of a separate unit, given that the proposal has been submitted as a householder application, and that the submitted drawings do not indicate that it would be used as separate accommodation, officers consider that it would not be used for any other purpose other than ancillary/incidental use to the main dwelling house. In any case, a planning condition would secure this in the event of an approval.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Officers have assessed the impact on daylighting and sunlighting of the proposed rear extension, using the BRE, 45 Degree Rule to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities.Fire Safety London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer Comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

For the avoidance of doubt, please confirm the description 'Erection of a single storey rear extension. Roof extension with 2nos rear dormers and installation of 4nos front and 1 no rear rooflights. Fenestration and roof alteration.'

Please provide 'Sustainable Urban Drainage Report'. Details of the implementation, adoption, maintenance and management of a sustainable drainage system. The details shall include a timetable for its implementation and a management and maintenance plan for the lifetime of the development which shall include the arrangements for adoption by any public body or statutory undertaker, or any other arrangements to secure the effective operation of the sustainable drainage system throughout its lifetime.If your development does not include SUDS you should demonstrate that such measures are not feasible and give details of how drainage will be dealt with.
Please provide bin and cycle storage details.

Site Location Plan - We cannot accept the submitted Site Location Plan as we cannot accept copies of plans such as your title deeds that were created for other purposes. The plan must be accurately scaled 1:1250 with the application site outlined in red, showing at least two road frontages and a North point.

Please provide Existing and Proposed Floor Plans at a recognised scale (at 1:50 or 1:100 for example), showing the outline of the entire floor plan, not just part and all key dimensions for the proposed works. The plans must also show the direction of North. Although the inclusion of a scale bar is not mandatory, it is encouraged.

Please provide all Existing and Proposed Elevations at a recognised scale (at 1:50 or 1:100 for example), showing all elevations not just part and indicating all key dimensions for the proposed work. Although the inclusion of a scale bar is not mandatory, it is encouraged.

Please provide Existing and Proposed Roof Plans at a recognised scale (at 1:50 or 1:100 for example), showing the outline of the entire property not just part and showing dimensions of the proposed work. The plans must show the direction of North. Although the inclusion of a scale bar is not mandatory, it is highly encouraged.
